TA/Mentor Code of Conduct

All course staff are expected to complete all required duties and adhere to the TA code of conduct. Remember, this is a job: if you don't get your work done, your timesheets may be rejected (since you haven't done your job), you may not be offered a position in subsequent semesters, and we may refuse to write you a letter of recommendation.

Ethical breaches that harm the integrity of the course are likely to result in immediate dismissal from the course staff and referral to the Office of Student Conduct.

  • Do not reveal confidential information (including reference implementations and grading rubrics).
  • Do not store confidential information (including any records that identify students) in private e-mail accounts or cloud storage. For FERPA compliance, you must use your UPenn e-mail and FERPA-compliant partners (Piazza and Google@SEAS/SAS/Wharton).
  • Do not give help privately over e-mail. Instead, direct students to piazza (using a private thread if necessary). If e-mail is necessary, cc or bcc cis110@cis. This rule is meant more than anything to protect you. It allows us to intervene early to deal with problems when necessary, and avoids unpleasant surprises. For example, we have seem private e-mail threads with TAs show up in OSC investigations, and that can get very messy for you as well as for us. If we're in the loop, we can head this off.
  • Never give help outside the structures of the course! This includes informally helping friends or students in your dorm as well as private tutoring (paid or unpaid) on the side. This is an extremely serious conflict of interest and may get you fired and/or referred to the OSC. If you have time to dedicate to giving help, answer piazza posts or work extra office hours (if there is demand). This rule also protects the separation between your work and private lives: if students corner you in your dorm to ask question, you may simply answer, "I'm not allowed to help you outside of office hours/piazza."
  • Do not meet privately with students without our knowledge. This is also an extremely serious conflict of interest that may get you fired and/or referred to the OSC. We routinely ask TAs to meet individually with their own students to help them catch up; such meetings must always be reported on your timesheets. It is extremely unusual for us to ask a TA or mentor to meet privately with a student from a different recitation, and you should never do so without our permission.

    It may be appropriate for you to reach out to struggling students in your own recitation and offer to meet with them. If you do that, you must inform us immediately. The easiest way to do this is to cc or bcc us on your e-mail.

  • Do not contradict official course policy, homework instructions, coding style guidelines, etc. You are responsible for knowing, following, and supporting everything we announce to students, and following all instructions we give in announcements to you or in staff meeting. This is pretty dictatorial, but you've probably had a class where the TAs and instructors were not in step and know how much trouble that can cause.
  • Complete all duties in a timely manner. These duties may include (but are not necessarily limited to):
    • grading;
    • recording grades, attendance, and pariticpation;
    • planning recitation;
    • teaching recitation;
    • holding office hours;
    • completing assignments by the TA deadline;
    • monitoring piazza;
    • attending staff meeting, TA training, and lecture;
    • completing timesheets
    Make a weekly checklist for yourself of your duties. Failure to complete any of your duties will result in your timesheets being held until you are completely caught up, and may result in timesheets being rejected.


  • Keep in close contact with your co-TA to plan your recitation and to plan ahead together for busy weeks. It is your joint responsibility to get your grading and office hours done, no matter how busy are otherwise. It is also your joint responsibility to plan out how you will run your recitation effectively together. We consistently see a difference in student evaluations between pairs of TAs that meet ahead of each recitation to plan it in detail and pairs (even experienced pairs) that "wing it."
  • Do your Piazza shifts. This means reading and answering all questions frequently throughout the day, and knowing what questions have been asked so you refer to existing answers rather than repeating them. It is not Scott's job to do this alone!
  • Promptly report any time conflicts or situations that may prevent you from getting work done on time to us, to the head TAs, and to your partner. This does not relieve you of your responsibilities, but it does help us find a way to make sure they are met.
  • Promptly report any kudos or concerns about other members of the course staff, including your partner, to the instructors or head TAs. We will not immediately fire (or promote) anyone just because you tell us something, but we can solve many issues early if we know about them. For instance, if we learn early that a member of the course staff is frequently missing or tardy to office hours, we may be able help that person get back on track. If we only learn belatedly after the problem has gotten serious, we may have no alternative but to not re-hire them.
  • Submit all homeworks by the TA deadline. You may work together with other TAs on the assignments (with proper credit in your readme), but you must complete each assignment from scratch. You may not use the reference implementation, and you may not resubmit your version from a previous semester. Assignments change in subtle ways each semester, and you must know the current version before it goes out to students.
